answers.q: can you use coconut oil with silicone toys
answers.a: Coconut oil isn’t the same as silicone oil (dimethylpolysiloxane/E900a); silicone oils can swell or degrade silicone toys, whereas plant oils like coconut oil usually don’t react the same way but are messy to clean and not condom‑safe—follow the toy maker’s guidance.

answers.q: is coconut oil safe for silicone toys
answers.a: Manufacturers typically warn against silicone oils (like dimethicone/E900a) with silicone toys; coconut oil may be less likely to affect the silicone itself but can be hard to sanitize and is incompatible with latex condoms—check the product’s instructions.
Silicone oil (dimethylpolysiloxane, E900a) is considered inert and of low toxicity; major regulators allow it as a food antifoaming agent at very low levels.

answers.q: what is silicone oil used for
answers.a: Dimethylpolysiloxane (E900a) is used as an antifoaming agent in foods and frying oils, and more broadly as a lubricant/release agent in personal care, medical, and industrial applications.
At approved food-use levels, it’s regarded as safe and minimally absorbed by the body, with no evidence of harm at those levels from major regulators.

Dimethicone is an inert silicone used as a skin protectant and moisturizer and is generally non‑irritating and suitable for sensitive skin. Very occlusive formulas may feel heavy and can aggravate breakouts in a small minority.
Not typically; it coats hair to reduce friction, frizz, and tangles, but can build up with frequent use and weigh down fine hair, so an occasional clarifying wash can help.
Yes—dimethicone (polydimethylsiloxane) is a type of silicone oil.
It's considered non‑comedogenic and unlikely to clog pores on its own, but as a film‑former it can trap sweat or other comedogenic ingredients on the skin in some individuals.
Yes; it's widely considered safe in cosmetics and is approved as a food antifoaming additive (E900A) at low permitted levels by regulators such as the FDA and EFSA, with irritation being rare.
